title: Time Magazine ancient nameplate (1920s)
content:
Does anybody knows what font graced this ( [http://www.time.com/time/covers/0,16641,19261018,00.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20071016223037/http:/www.time.com/time/covers/0,16641,19261018,00.html "http://www.time.com/time/covers/0,16641,19261018,00.html")) Time Magazine cover from the 1920s?

Thanks  
A.

 [‹ (x) Wendy's current campaign font - Neutraface {Akira}](http://web.archive.org/web/20071016223037/http:/typophile.com/node/37672 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) New York Cosmos logo - Othello (PL Fiorello Cond) {Akira (Rainer)} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20071016223037/http:/typophile.com/node/37588 "Go to next forum topic")
author: abaldoni

comments.content: This was hand lettered — or custom designed if you will. Nowadays it is easy as pie to enlarge the font in your design program at will, but back then every size had to be cut and cast. We’re talking entirely different production methods here. Any type quite large — especially magazine nameplates and slogans in advertisements — was done by hand.
Type “trajan” at Myfonts.com and see what’s fit to your need.
Trajan? No way, the M doesn’t match at all. Maybe Weiss Antiqua or Berling. Check FontShop.com.
Also Felix Titling and Carlton exude that same vintage atmosphere.
Hm, I’m quite off the mark here. Let me check for better matches.

So, let’s take a look at [Felix Titling](http://web.archive.org/web/20071016223037/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/monotype/felix_titling/?sample_text=TIME&sample_size=96). Already quite close.

You might like [FB Californian Display](http://web.archive.org/web/20071016223037/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/font_bureau/californian_3_display/?sample_text=TIME&sample_size=96) or [Goudy Saks](http://web.archive.org/web/20071016223037/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/richard_beatty/goudy_saks_sc_osf/?sample_text=TIME&sample_size=96) as well. [Goudy Oldstyle](http://web.archive.org/web/20071016223037/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/monotype/goudy_std/?sample_text=TIME&sample_size=96) has the correct type of M, but the serifs are too pronounced.

When I compare all these options, I get the impression this nameplate may have been done by [Frederic W. Goudy](http://web.archive.org/web/20071016223037/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Frederic%252BW.%252BGoudy) himself.
